div1.p: Reed Home Now is Practically Like Original

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Times-Herald, August 12, 1927
div1.p: THE TIMES-HERALD. NEWPORT NEWS, VIRGINIA, FRIDAY, AUGUST 12, 1927.

REED HOME NOW
IS PRACTICALLY
LIKE ORIGINAL

Home of Dr. Walter Reed Has
Been Rebuilt so as to Conform
as Nearly as Possible to the
Way It Appeared at the Time
the Famous Physician Was
Born.

Having been rebuilt so as to conform
as nearly as possible to the way it
looked at the time of Dr. Walter Reed's
birth, Belroi, the home of the noted
physician, soon will be restored and
be made into a shrine as a memorial
to the man who discovered the mos-
quito to be a carrier of yellow fever,
and who in other ways devoted his
time, his energy and his money to im-
proving the general health of the
public.

Dr. Clarence Porter Jones, active
member of the Walter Reed Mem-
orial association, went yesterday to
the old home to view the progress
made by the workmen, taking as his
guests, Dr. George Williams, J. L.
Kibler and W. S. Copeland. Those
who made the trip stated that the
work has been all but finished, with
only a few minor details remaining
to be attended to.

The old house has been almost re-
built, with new weather boarding on
the sides and rear of the building,
the front being covered with rem-
nants of the original weather-stam
ed clapboards which formerly
sheahed the house. The old floors
have been preserved and most of the
doors. The mantlepieces which
stood over the hearths in the days
of the famous physician's youth have
been restored with one of the orig-
inals in the rear room and a very
close replica having been placed in
the living room.

The house is only one and one-half
stories high, with two rooms on the
first floor and a small guest room
above. The dimensions of the house
are 24 by 21 feet, the rear room, in
which the noted man was born, be-
ing little more than a leanto, though
under the same roof with the living
room. There were originally two
chimneys to the house, but the fam-
ily which recently lived there had
the front chimney torn down and
an additional room built. During the
work of restoration this room was
removed and the chimney rebuilt
with the same bricks from which it
was first constructed.

The floors and walls of the build-
ing are in good shape, it was said,
little being necessary in the way of
repairs to the floor and the walls,
being freshened and preserved by a
coat of white finishing. A new shing-
le roof as been put on the house and
the entire exterior treated with
priming and white paint. An old
log kitchen which formerly stood in
the rear of the dwelling will be re-
stored in the near fture.

The building is surrounded by an
acre of ground, with a crepe myrtle
and walnut tree which stood in the
yard during the youth of the man
whose memory is enshrined within
the walls of the little house, still
casting their shade on the lawn. The
grounds has not as yet been given
much attention as yet, but the as-
sociation intends to beautify them
and build a permanent fence about
the place. It is the hope of those in-
terested in the restoration of Belroi,
to make it a museum to the memory
of the man who first saw the light
of day within its narrow confines by
the gradual acquisition of the old
furniture, books and various articles
connected with the boyhood and the
manhood of Dr. Walter Reed.

The place is now in first class
condition, being beautifully situated
and those who have seen the work
of transformation declare that when
the work on the grounds has been
accomplished that it will be one of
the most attractive spots in the
vicinity.
